newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgium told after fact of Renault plant closure.
newsitem.headline: Belgium told after fact of Renault plant closure.

text.p: Belgian Prime Minister Jean-Luc Dehaene, fending off French criticism, said on Wednesday French car maker Renault had told him ahead of time of heavy losses and the need for drastic measures, but a decision to close its Belgian plant had reached him after the fact.
In a statement Dehaene said management told him of trouble at Renault on February 21, adding that the closure of the assembly plant at Vilvoorde near Brussels was an option.
Dehaene said that already he then told Renault "this hypothesis" should be ruled out and was totally unacceptable.
On Wednesday February 26 Dehaene was told by the Flemish regional government Renault had decided to close Vilvoorde.
The news was broken to the 3,100 Renault Industrie Belgique workers on February 27 and Dehaene, who lives in Vilvoorde, publicly condemned the decision as unacceptable.
A day later the government complained that Belgian and European Union information and consultation procedures had not been followed and decided to sue Renault.

In a radio interview French Industry Minister Franck Borotra defended Renault, saying the company had informed the French and Belgian governments of the decision to close Vilvoorde a few days before the official announcement.

But later he told parliament there had been gaps in the information supplied by Renault, adding that President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Alain Juppe "were not in agreement with the method" Renault used.
Renault chief executive officer Louis Schweitzer was summoned to a meeting with Juppe later on Wednesday afternoon.
The summons reflected an abrupt change in tactics by the French authorities, who had previously avoided criticism of the firm's decision to close the Vilvoorde plant.
It appeared to reflect concern about potential damage to France's image and interests in Belgium and beyond, and about the risk of industrial unrest spreading to France.
